title: packr-vignette
text: vignette illustrate use dataset utility functions included package packr. collected data set initially use course GEOG 3LT3: Transportation Geography. part course, students examine trends transportation, including use energy emissions. objective practice two-fold: side technology, students learning work R Notebooks R. reason, code documented students can see things done. side transportation geography, students learning discern trends transportation.

title: packr-vignette
text: load data, use function data(): inspect dataframe, use function summary() data frame consists 10 variables. variable definitions can consulted help file:
code: data("energy_and_emmisions") #> Warning in data("energy_and_emmisions"): data set 'energy_and_emmisions' not #> found summary(energy_and_emissions) #>    Country               Area            Population                   PYear     #>  Length:188         Min.   :      54   Min.   :5.292e+03   JULY 2017 EST.:188   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:   25618   1st Qu.:1.955e+06                        #>  Mode  :character   Median :  113098   Median :8.101e+06                        #>                     Mean   :  666756   Mean   :3.847e+07                        #>                     3rd Qu.:  479278   3rd Qu.:2.558e+07                        #>                     Max.   :16377742   Max.   :1.379e+09                        #>      GDPPC            bblpd           EYear        CO2_1995       #>  Min.   :   145   Min.   :     400   2014:148   Min.   :     12   #>  1st Qu.:  1817   1st Qu.:   13000   2015: 34   1st Qu.:    936   #>  Median :  5620   Median :   53000   2016:  6   Median :   6661   #>  Mean   : 13572   Mean   :  490635              Mean   : 121256   #>  3rd Qu.: 16148   3rd Qu.:  255500              3rd Qu.:  61534   #>  Max.   :100161   Max.   :19530000              Max.   :5294648   #>     CO2_2005          CO2_2015           Continent  #>  Min.   :     14   Min.   :      28   Africa  :50   #>  1st Qu.:   1379   1st Qu.:    2153   Americas:41   #>  Median :   8434   Median :   10062   Asia    :47   #>  Mean   : 152549   Mean   :  184978   Europe  :36   #>  3rd Qu.:  62283   3rd Qu.:   75294   Oceania :12   #>  Max.   :6174717   Max.   :10641789   NA's    : 2 ?energy_and_emissions #> No documentation for 'energy_and_emissions' in specified packages and libraries: #> you could try '??energy_and_emissions'

what: Are population and oil consumption related?
title: packr-vignette
text: dataframe includes information population, GDP per capita, energy consumption, emissions world countries. consumption energy (barrels per day) country. can plot two variables see trend. create scatterplot x = Population y = bblpd, values population mapped x-axis, values energy consumption mapped y-axis:  suprisingly, strong association two variables, since countries big populations consume energy small countries small populations. informative, underlying relationship simply size.
code: # Simple Scatterplot plot(energy_and_emissions$Population,      energy_and_emissions$bblpd,       main="Scatterplot Example",      xlab="Population ",       ylab="Barrels of oil per day ",       pch=19)

what: What is the per capita consumption of oil by country?
title: packr-vignette
text: Instead exploring energy consumption population, look energy consumption per capita. informative variable, normalizes size, potentially can tell us something intensity /efficiency energy use. However, energy consumption per capita one variables dataset. need divide variable bblpd Population add variable dataframe: Check descriptive statistics EPC (energy consumption barrels per day per person): maximum consumption approximately 0.22 barrels per person per day. country ? country highest per capita oil consumption world according data Singapore.
code: energy_and_emissions$EPC <- energy_and_emissions$bblpd/energy_and_emissions$Population summary(energy_and_emissions$EPC) #>      Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean   3rd Qu.      Max.  #> 0.0001308 0.0035039 0.0107354 0.0211934 0.0270790 0.2193948 energy_and_emissions[energy_and_emissions$EPC == max(energy_and_emissions$EPC), "Country"] #> [1] "SINGAPORE"

what: Are GDP per capita and energy consumption per capita related?
title: packr-vignette
text: answer question, can create scatterplot two variables:  Calculate correlation two variables: moderately strong correlation two variables. learn analysis? extend analysis?
code: plot(energy_and_emissions$GDPPC,       energy_and_emissions$EPC,       main="Scatterplot Example",      xlab="GDP per capita ",       ylab="Energy consumption per capita (bbpd/population) ",       pch=19) cor(energy_and_emissions$GDPPC, energy_and_emissions$EPC) #> [1] 0.6239777

title: Authors and Citation
text: Paez (2024). packr: Minimal Example Package Creation. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://paezha.github.io/packr/, https://github.com/paezha/packr.
code: @Manual{,   title = {packr: A Minimal Example of Package Creation},   author = {Antonio Paez},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://paezha.github.io/packr/},   url = {https://github.com/paezha/packr}, }

what: A Minimal Example of Package Creation
title: A Minimal Example of Package Creation
text: goal packr present minimal example package creation R. uses {usethis} functions create package, license, README.Rmd file, well documentation appropriate folders data.

title: A Minimal Example of Package Creation
text: can install development version packr GitHub :

title: A Minimal Example of Package Creation
text: basic example shows use package: special using README.Rmd instead just README.md? can include R chunks like : ’ll still need render README.Rmd regularly, keep README.md --date. devtools::build_readme() handy . also use GitHub Actions re-render README.Rmd every time push. example workflow can found : https://github.com/r-lib/actions/tree/master/examples. can also embed plots, example: case, don’t forget commit push resulting figure files, display GitHub CRAN. , can include equations: ![ x^2 + y^2 = z^2](https://latex.codecogs.com/png.latex?%0Ax%5E2%20%2B%20y%5E2%20%3D%20z%5E2%0A ” x^2 + y^2 = z^2 “) Trying github pages now.
code: library(packr) summary(energy_and_emissions) #>    Country               Area            Population                   PYear     #>  Length:188         Min.   :      54   Min.   :5.292e+03   JULY 2017 EST.:188   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:   25618   1st Qu.:1.955e+06                        #>  Mode  :character   Median :  113098   Median :8.101e+06                        #>                     Mean   :  666756   Mean   :3.847e+07                        #>                     3rd Qu.:  479278   3rd Qu.:2.558e+07                        #>                     Max.   :16377742   Max.   :1.379e+09                        #>      GDPPC            bblpd           EYear        CO2_1995       #>  Min.   :   145   Min.   :     400   2014:148   Min.   :     12   #>  1st Qu.:  1817   1st Qu.:   13000   2015: 34   1st Qu.:    936   #>  Median :  5620   Median :   53000   2016:  6   Median :   6661   #>  Mean   : 13572   Mean   :  490635              Mean   : 121256   #>  3rd Qu.: 16148   3rd Qu.:  255500              3rd Qu.:  61534   #>  Max.   :100161   Max.   :19530000              Max.   :5294648   #>     CO2_2005          CO2_2015           Continent  #>  Min.   :     14   Min.   :      28   Africa  :50   #>  1st Qu.:   1379   1st Qu.:    2153   Americas:41   #>  Median :   8434   Median :   10062   Asia    :47   #>  Mean   : 152549   Mean   :  184978   Europe  :36   #>  3rd Qu.:  62283   3rd Qu.:   75294   Oceania :12   #>  Max.   :6174717   Max.   :10641789   NA's    : 2
